name: 4-methyloctane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The base structure for 4-methyloctane is octane, which has a melting point of around -57°C. The addition of a methyl group at the 4-position introduces a branching in the molecule, which disrupts the regular packing of molecules in the solid phase, thus lowering the melting point compared to the straight-chain counterpart. Given that the actual value for the melting point of 4-methyloctane is significantly lower than the predicted range, the estimated effect of the methyl group needs to be reassessed. The actual data suggests that the introduction of branching via a methyl group has a larger impact on the melting point than initially considered. A reevaluation of the effect of the methyl group might approximate a shift of around -56 to -61°C, to be consistent with the known actual value.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit for comparison is octane, which has a melting point of -138.7°C. The addition of a methyl group to a hydrocarbon chain generally increases the melting point due to an increase in van der Waals forces; this effect can be estimated to be +20°C.
